nt. This becomes
clear when we contrast this conditional with a statement that does formu-
late an argument:
Conditional:Ifthe Dodgers improve their hitting, thenthey will win the 
Western Division.
Argument:Sincethe Dodgers will improve their hitting, they will win the 
Western Division.
The sentence that follows the word “since” is asserted. That is why “since”
is an argument marker, whereas the connective “if . . . then . . .” is not an
argument marker.
